NEVER. dared to play this game, because when I first saw it more than two decades ago the skill system seemed so overwhelming. I am glad I did now, if you tackle one thing at a time theres time for us adults to make progress in this game. There is nothing rushing you to make progress, you can go at your own pase and theres really no order to do stuff. Its a very open game.

More refine version of OSRS regardless of how many people dislike it, coming from a 2013 player this RS3 is heading the right directions!

It's alright, a side game you can return to when you have nothing to play. Something rare in the MMO space with most modern ones end of servicing within 5 years.

My husband grew up playing this, I did not (I was a gaia online, maple story and WOW girly). He has continued to play well into adulthood and, after 11 years of being with him I decided to finally pick it up. I love it! Being a 90's gamer, I don't need 4k graphics or 120+ FPS to enjoy a game and I am completely okay with click and point gaming long as its engaging. RS is successful in these aspects, and I love that the developers care for their community and actually take their opinions seriously. I'm thoroughly enjoying my run of the game and highly recommend if you need something fun and doesn;t require to much of your attention.

I enjoy the casual silliness of the game. the quest line in the timeline order is a great way to experience the game, and make yourself feel rewarded for more for leveling rather than just grinding to see big numbers.

Making in game currency is very easy, and you should never be actually broke if you spend a little time each day doing what are referred to as "shop runs" everyday.

so far the people in game have been courteous, helpful and kind when they are not AFK.
Spent to long looking for osrs likes when i got burnout from the grind, this fits perfectly to what i wanted and excited to see the game grow now that MTX is being removed in Janurary!!
its a life style and its well worth it lool! get summmm rs3 or osrs! they both rock

RuneScape is one of the longest running MMORPG's, and it's well earned its place. With a rich soundtrack, a densely populated world of interesting characters and gorgeous locations, and a nearly countless amount of quests and challenges, one can spend years on the game and still be less than halfway through it.

The main gameplay loop of RuneScape is repetition in the form of training skills or earning money, which may be either a deterrent or a bonus depending on the player. Since the game does not require heavy performance, I have found it easy to run the game on one screen or window while doing other things at the same time.
great game to pass time has alot to do plus to keep busy while you do other little things plus stays updated
Pretty chill and cozy. Has my oldest online account of almost 20 years.
great game expansive world Alot to do slow start at the start but gets amazingly entertaining the more you play and build up your account
Grew up with this game and might die with it. <3 Exploration is unlimited, various things to achieve almost unlimited as well.

Ive played this game for a long time, about 20 years, and have closer to 5000 hours in game. It has had some dark times (2012 to 2024), but it seems that its coming back from the hell hole path it was going down for all that time. Luckily, there is a new CEO that genuinely seems to want to restore the health of the game and it seems that he is doing that. 
 They are taking away the predatory micro transactions that have haunted the game since 2012, and they are also backing away from forcing gay propaganda into the game. The game is old as hell, and at a surface level it look dull and pointless. But beyond that, it is a game that has such incredible depth and I, for one, am glad its finally coming back to being the great game it was pre 2012.
I recommend the game, but it is certainly not for everyone.

Besides nostalgia, (though osrs is more for that) it's actually a very decent game. Sure it can be grindy. And while it's free, membership is a must for all the Steam achievements. 

Nevertheless it's an enjoyable game to me. Might be very grindy for f2p (can get much further on quests alone as a member). Definitely worth a try. And you can get membership for free with ingame currency. Though sadly, It's still expensive. 

The community is massive. There are guides for pretty much everything. Sadly Runescape itself doesn't have their forums anymore and Zybez is also dead. But nevertheless. It's a great way to bring back memories of old. And make new ones.

The only real issue I have is thousands of microtransactions. It feels like EA not Jagex. Monthly membership I understand, but encouraging me to buy keys or cosmetics after every login gets old quick.

it's a pretty fun game! i do wish that it was a bit easier to tell how to get bonds in the game for membership, well, then again i wish the membership thing wasn't an option, or had a seperate world map for all the membership stuff. but outside of that i see myself putting so many hours into this game now that i am able to play it on steam

I have about 10,000 hours in RuneScape and if you like:

Gaining xp/wealth (watching numbers go up like in idle games)
Fast and engaging combat
Dozens of unique bosses and a few raid/group bosses
Multiple ways to play
A relaxed gaming experience
Skills that you can AFK
Nostalgic feel of playing RuneScape again
Or you just think this game looks cool and want to give it a go

I will be the first to tell you to stay as far away from this game as possible. Once you start there is really no escape. You might take some time off and think you‚Äôve quit but you‚Äôll come back. You‚Äôll always come back. Then, before you know it, you‚Äôll have been playing for almost 15 years and have about 10,000 hours in the game.

Honestly, playing RuneScape is like clapping. Once you start you never really stop. The intervals between playing (claps) might increase but you never truly stop.

Anyways, Jagex, thanks for an alright first 10,000 hours and here‚Äôs to the next 10,000. Cheers.

One of the greatest MMO ever made. Original and unique (whereas newer MMOs tend to feel like they're copypasted from each other), it's a real RPG adventure (not a min-max grindfest), with actual amazing quests (better than any other MMO) filled with intriguing lore and an entertaining atmosphere, amazing music and an on-point sense of humour. The graphics, which in certain areas really show their age, add a sense of history which is charming and gives the game an identity; let yourself not be deceived, though: this is not a ridiculous fossil such as OSRS, but a living, well kept game with a tight update schedule and kept in time with what is expected of an MMO nowadays, plus its amazing, thriving community which numbers in the millions. For a game so cheap (in fact, you can play a lot of it for free!) with a company so small in budget and size, it sure has worked miracles in the 20 years of its history. 8/10.
With over 1000 hours on this game, I think I liked it.  Numbers go up and you get a dopamine release every time.  Also fun to chat with people while farming for materials or whatever.

It's the classic grind and make number go up and feel good game. Its a good time, but there is currently a big issue with p2w MTX slop.

P.S. Wiki is your friend.

I have never taken interest in fantasy MMORPGs until NOW. It's surprisingly VERY fun and chill. This is such a good game especially if you're a casual player who wants to sit down, relax and play a game.
10/10
I have been playing Runescape for almost 25 years! Even if i stop playing for a year i always come back. Great game if youre into grinding.

‚ÄúRuneScape 3: Where Time Goes to Die‚Äù

Imagine logging in (just to do a farm run) and suddenly it‚Äôs 4 hours later, your virtual potatoes are thriving, but your real ones in the oven are charcoal. RS3 is basically a financial advisor in disguise it teaches you that sunk cost fallacy is real, and that you‚Äôll happily grind 200 hours for a cape that gives a +4% chance to not burn digital fish.

The graphics? Surprisingly decent for a game that also runs on toasters. The combat? It‚Äôs like playing piano on your keyboard while your boss monster judges your rotation. The quests? Absolute masterpieces until you realize the gnome you helped 10 years ago now requires 95 Archaeology, a PhD in puzzles, and the patience of a monk.

The community? Equal parts kind, helpful, and terrifyingly rich people who own more in-game than most countries‚Äô GDP.

10/10 would AFK woodcutting while questioning my life choices again.
Used to play it when I was in middle school and its nice remembering how fun this game used to be and still is.

Although this game has been out for MANY years i just started playing it for the first time in Aug 2025 and i find it to be an excellent game.  Engaging, plenty to do for hours and hours of enjoyment.  I highly recommend it!!
one of the best games in the world... old school is better but i cant help but love rs3 becuase its still runescape!!!!!!!

My grandad got me into RuneScape when I was about nine. After dinner he‚Äôd pull up a second chair to the old desktop, hand me a cup of tea, and we‚Äôd spend an hour or two chopping those Yew trees next to the GE or killing spiders together. He never got past bronze armour and thought the Grand Exchange was ‚Äúfancy nonsense,‚Äù but he loved the quiet rhythm of it‚Äîfishing lobsters while we talked about school or his time in the navy. He passed away when I was fifteen, and I still can‚Äôt hear the old OST without thinking of him. It was never about the game, really; it was just time with him.

One of the best and most consistently enjoyable MMORPGs ever made and it's 25 years old. I'd like to see someone make a better F2P MMORPG that actually rewards your time and effort. Played a lot back in Middle School and as returning player at age 31, all the fun and wonderful memories are back.

The ban appeal process is almost entirely illegitimate. Once the automated system tags you for botting or macroing, you have almost no hope of getting justice, no matter how much time you put into your character or how much money you paid. I only play this game because it has no competition in the genre.

The quests are some of the best there is, skilling is pretty great, and I love what they did with archaeology, necromancy is really cool too except for the bossing requirements. endgame is a LOT of bossing and its all awful. the timing of mechanics is waaay too punishing for how high the tick length is. needs some sort of visual indicator for tick timings or SOMETHING. I've been playing this game for nearly 20 years now, but bossing has steadily more and more catered to the top 5% of players, There have been some efforts recently to fix this, but all efforts so far have been lipstick on a pig.
i would like to play but right away alll the customization screens, shadows, and character/item portraits are glitching out...

Horrendously boring. Bloated skill systems and the point and click makes one feel like the tutorial never ends. I don't even know what the story would be, that needs to be present first before you make me cook food and do meandering fetch quests. Vibrant quests at 30+ probably but to get there is a slog. Not worth the effort.

TLDR: Skilling is the main game. Quests are cool. The combat is not fun. Game servers are old. MTX is bad, but Ironman goes brrrr. Everything you do builds towards endgame bossing, so keep that in mind when you do your vibe check.

I've put in 10k hours on this game over the decades and there is plenty to do in the game, plenty of people to meet and hang out with, and it is easy to lose weeks or months to this game. RS3 and OSRS are glorified spreadsheet, checklist, cookie clicker MMORPGs. Progress is permanent and there is always something new to complete. It is satisfying looking back at where you started and seeing how far you've come.

The life skilling content is overabundant and great if that's what you're looking for in an MMO. The content varies heavily from high APM activities to "AFK" activities where you can play RS on a second or even third monitor. It seems like the devs mostly play skilling content and they prefer making more of this content, so if you like it then you'll always have something to look forward to.

The quests and lore is 95% great. Some recent stories were shat out to push agendas, but they have zero impact on the world and can be ignored pretty easily. Some of the quest lines are legendary and truly impressive storytelling. If you're not locking into one quest line and jumping around, be prepared for some extreme shifts in tone.

The combat content is also very massive with plenty of bosses to learn, collection logs to complete, and achievements to showcase your mastery and dedication to the content. The actual combat itself is confusing and clunky and requires hundreds of hours of research off platform to figure out how to play. The tooltips aren't clear, the animations are copy pasted, the audio cues are few and far between, and damage just seems to happen with no indication on where the damage came from.

There are some other server related jank like the tick system and the ground tile system which is an extreme problem in this game and OSRS, but OSRS has better accessibility with RuneLite where ingame tick metronomes and true tile markers help you see past the jank. You can overcome this if you like the content enough, but you need to understand that what the server sees is different than what your client is showing you. The visuals are lying to you.

Micro-transactions are also a huge problem in this game, you can buy gold, xp, double xp, loot boxes, and cosmetics. Fortunately you can ignore this by playing the many Ironman Modes which transforms the game into a competitive self-funded solo MMO and it disables the cash shops for leaderboard integrity. But you'll get months where there are no updates outside of the cash shop and those periods of time feel like all the dev time is going towards the shop, not the game. (There appears to be a culture shift going on in 2025 so maybe this will slowly go away.) Your mileage will very.

Overall, the game is building towards endgame combat. Every skill, quest and monster you kill is preparing you for killing the bosses. If you don't like the combat and don't want to fight the bosses then your enjoyment of the rest of the game may feel meaningless. You can over-level and use power creep to trivialize most early bosses, but those bosses usually serve the purpose of preparing you for the next boss in the ladder, playing this way won't magically make you enjoy the combat if it misses your initial vibe check.

I lost 11 Ancient Scales during a Seriyu kill because of the long-standing ‚Äúno loot / no KC‚Äù bug ‚Äî it happens when you kill the last crystal on the same tick you‚Äôre thrown off the platform. The game registers the kill but gives no loot or kill-count.

I submitted a detailed report to support and got a canned response claiming ‚Äúno valid items were lost outside of intended game mechanics.‚Äù Even though this is a known issue, they refuse to help or acknowledge it.

It‚Äôs not about the GP ‚Äî it‚Äôs about trust. If Jagex can‚Äôt fix or stand behind small, verifiable bugs, how can anyone believe they‚Äôll take care of bigger ones?
I‚Äôve cancelled my membership after years of play. Sad to see how far RuneScape has fallen from what it used to be.

I was really enjoying the game, The quests were cute, due to the free keys it was pretty fast to get skills up for early game content (Though I did feel a tad OP). I will flat out that I find this game better than old school runescape.

Then I saw the price.... $20 Australian a month? Are you takin the mickey jagex? They have got to be right? NOPE that is the price of the game, it is WILDLY overpriced for what it is. Yes, it's fun, Yes I enjoyed the free content... But NO, it's not worth $20 a month... MAYBE $20 as a once off, or a $5 a month but $20? Well that was the end of my Runescape experience, I would rather put that $20 a month into my wow account where I could literally turn it into millions of gold....

You have to pay $14 for each alt subscription. So if you like having alts, be ready to fork over A LOT of money. It's insane and greedy in my opinion, it's morally wrong. It really turns me away from wanting to make Item Shop purchases in the future :/ 

Why not do things that are good for the players and the game? Then customers will be more than willing to make even purchases. instead, I feel like Jagex is trying to take advantage of it's players and not offer a fair market value trade for the transactions. 

It's just a bad way to feel as a customer.

The ban appeal process is almost entirely illegitimate. Once the automated system tags you for botting or macroing, you have almost no hope of getting justice, no matter how much time you put into your character or how much money you paid. I only play this game because it has no competition in the genre.

The quests are some of the best there is, skilling is pretty great, and I love what they did with archaeology, necromancy is really cool too except for the bossing requirements. endgame is a LOT of bossing and its all awful. the timing of mechanics is waaay too punishing for how high the tick length is. needs some sort of visual indicator for tick timings or SOMETHING. I've been playing this game for nearly 20 years now, but bossing has steadily more and more catered to the top 5% of players, There have been some efforts recently to fix this, but all efforts so far have been lipstick on a pig.
i would like to play but right away alll the customization screens, shadows, and character/item portraits are glitching out...

Horrendously boring. Bloated skill systems and the point and click makes one feel like the tutorial never ends. I don't even know what the story would be, that needs to be present first before you make me cook food and do meandering fetch quests. Vibrant quests at 30+ probably but to get there is a slog. Not worth the effort.

TLDR: Skilling is the main game. Quests are cool. The combat is not fun. Game servers are old. MTX is bad, but Ironman goes brrrr. Everything you do builds towards endgame bossing, so keep that in mind when you do your vibe check.

I've put in 10k hours on this game over the decades and there is plenty to do in the game, plenty of people to meet and hang out with, and it is easy to lose weeks or months to this game. RS3 and OSRS are glorified spreadsheet, checklist, cookie clicker MMORPGs. Progress is permanent and there is always something new to complete. It is satisfying looking back at where you started and seeing how far you've come.

The life skilling content is overabundant and great if that's what you're looking for in an MMO. The content varies heavily from high APM activities to "AFK" activities where you can play RS on a second or even third monitor. It seems like the devs mostly play skilling content and they prefer making more of this content, so if you like it then you'll always have something to look forward to.

The quests and lore is 95% great. Some recent stories were shat out to push agendas, but they have zero impact on the world and can be ignored pretty easily. Some of the quest lines are legendary and truly impressive storytelling. If you're not locking into one quest line and jumping around, be prepared for some extreme shifts in tone.

The combat content is also very massive with plenty of bosses to learn, collection logs to complete, and achievements to showcase your mastery and dedication to the content. The actual combat itself is confusing and clunky and requires hundreds of hours of research off platform to figure out how to play. The tooltips aren't clear, the animations are copy pasted, the audio cues are few and far between, and damage just seems to happen with no indication on where the damage came from.

There are some other server related jank like the tick system and the ground tile system which is an extreme problem in this game and OSRS, but OSRS has better accessibility with RuneLite where ingame tick metronomes and true tile markers help you see past the jank. You can overcome this if you like the content enough, but you need to understand that what the server sees is different than what your client is showing you. The visuals are lying to you.

Micro-transactions are also a huge problem in this game, you can buy gold, xp, double xp, loot boxes, and cosmetics. Fortunately you can ignore this by playing the many Ironman Modes which transforms the game into a competitive self-funded solo MMO and it disables the cash shops for leaderboard integrity. But you'll get months where there are no updates outside of the cash shop and those periods of time feel like all the dev time is going towards the shop, not the game. (There appears to be a culture shift going on in 2025 so maybe this will slowly go away.) Your mileage will very.

Overall, the game is building towards endgame combat. Every skill, quest and monster you kill is preparing you for killing the bosses. If you don't like the combat and don't want to fight the bosses then your enjoyment of the rest of the game may feel meaningless. You can over-level and use power creep to trivialize most early bosses, but those bosses usually serve the purpose of preparing you for the next boss in the ladder, playing this way won't magically make you enjoy the combat if it misses your initial vibe check.
